title: Put older versions (like 1.6) in git history
body: To better understand the changes, it’d be useful to redo the master branch to include the older versions.

title: Compilation failure.

title: findInterval fails
body:
Hi,
I am running histoneHMM 1.7 on a BAM file (DEEP project) for H3K9me3 and get the following error:
```R
Error in findInterval(x, quantile(x, prob = (0:ncomp)/ncomp), rightmost.closed = T) : 
  'vec' must be sorted non-decreasingly and not contain NAs
Calls: run.univariate.hmm -> em -> findInterval
```
Session:
```R
R version 3.3.2 (2016-10-31)
Platform: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu (64-bit)
Running under: Debian GNU/Linux 7 (wheezy)

locale:
 [1] LC_CTYPE=en_US       LC_NUMERIC=C         LC_TIME=en_US       
 [4] LC_COLLATE=C         LC_MONETARY=en_US    LC_MESSAGES=en_US   
 [7] LC_PAPER=en_US       LC_NAME=C            LC_ADDRESS=C        
[10] LC_TELEPHONE=C       LC_MEASUREMENT=en_US LC_IDENTIFICATION=C 

attached base packages:
[1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     

other attached packages:
[1] histoneHMM_1.7 Rcpp_0.12.8   
```
Best,
Peter

title: callRegions output avg.posterior as array type
body:
Hi,

`callRegions` calculates the average posterior by `tapply`, i.e. `reduced.posterior = apply(elementMetadata(called.granges)[,posterior.col], called2reduced[,2], mean, na.rm=T)`. Since the output of `tapply` is an `array` type by default, the `avg.posterior` field of `reduced.granges` is also of this type.

This turns out to cause breaking errors when using `makeGffAttributes` on `reduced.granges`, as `as.data.frame` in some versions of S4Vectors doesn't seem to properly parse a `DataFrame` with a field of `array` type. This in turns breaks `GR2gff`, and, thus, also breaks `histoneHMM_call_regions.R`.

On our side, one way to fix it is to coerce `reduced.posterior` (and, similarly, `reduced.expression`) to `numeric` before putting them in `mcols (reduced.granges)`.

title: make new release for conda
body:
The current git version seems to solve some problems/errors we get with histoneHMM.

Please make a new release so that we can get this also as a new conda version!
Thank you!

title: typo in histoneHMM_call_differential.R
body:
Hi! I've notcied that there is a missing comma behind this status when I was trying to run the script - 
 make_option("--baumwelch", action="store_false",
              help="Whether the Baum Welch algorithm should be used for
                    parameter estimation.")

title: question about input controls
body:
Hello,

Thank you for your work on histoneHMM! I have been using it to analyze some H3K27me3 ChIP-seq data. I just was wondering if you could clarify for me what the best way to include input controls per sample is, in your opinion? Would it be advisable to call differential peaks between IP & input first, and then use the significant peaks as input into other differential analyses? Or would you simply subtract any peaks that show up in the input as well? (Or something else I missed?)
